Hey Billo,
 
The Heritrix developers manual covers how to write processors =
and filters
for Heritrix. 
It would probably also be a good idea to run thr=
ough the user manual for a
quick overview of how the processing chain and p=
rocessors work in Heritrix.
 
What you are describing would probably be a p=
rocessor (like our link
extractors), it could 'discard' URIs that are of li=
ttle interest by skipping
over the link extraction / writing to disk etc. 
=
 
Both manuals can be found via http://crawler.archive.org
 
- Kris

-----O=
riginal Message-----
From: billo_ga [mailto:billo@...] 
Sent: 22. feb=
r=FAar 2005 13:10
To: archive-crawler@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [archive-cra=
wler] Re: Newbie question -- I should be more specific



--- In archive-cr=
awler@yahoogroups.com, "bergmark_d" <bergmark@C...>
wrote:
> 
> Not necessa=
ry to finish the crawl first and then examine the pages;
> you can write a =
processor that examines the pages on the fly, and
> continue to crawl only =
from pages of interest, or only write out 
> pages of interest.  To do this=
, you must parse the HTML, PDF, etc.
> on the fly.  (I have code examples i=
f you want to see how; maybe 
> this should be a section in the user manual=
 for Heritrix).  bergmark_d

This is what I want to do.  Let's say I find a=
n image archive of
10,000 pages, or an article archive with 50,000 articles=
.  It would be
easy to triage this to just a few hundred pages by simple se=
arch
criteria.  I would rather just download those few hundred to begin
wit=
h rather than grab zillions of pages and post process them.

If I could see=
 how you wrote such a module -- particularly how you get
it to work with he=
retrix, that would be wonderful.  I can write a
parser.  I don't have a clu=
e as to how to make it work with heretrix.

It would be extraordinarily use=
ful to have a short tutorial on how to
write modules/filters/whatever for h=
eretrix (I'm still not sure
whether this would be a "filter" or "module" or=
 what).

Thanks!

billo
